options.Doing Too Much: Make sure that you are still hitting the essentials, and carefully evaluating decisions around introducing additional elements (such as color).
options.Inaccurate: Some of the charts were inaccurate to what was expected from the instructions. Make sure to pick out essential pieces of the prompts and refer to the example visualizations to guide your process.

options.Late Verbage: Make sure to give yourself enough time to get the milestone in on time. Alternatively, if you have a valid reason for being late, make sure to reach out to HelpHub to get the extension. I want to make sure you get full credit for the work that you do.

options.Inaccurate: There are actually 10 men and no women in the top 10 highest paid.

options.Thorough and Insightful: Great analysis of the factors influencing the earnings of the top 3.
options.Concise: This has good factors that need to be expanded on. To take it a step further, you can use specific examples and or numbers.
options.Insufficient: There should be more detail here. Needs to address both the reason actors have earned so much over time, as well as what sources those earnings might come from.

options.Wrong Chart: Issues with the chart lead to inaccurate insights here. The Actor Earnings over Time chart should show the gap narrowing (and even temporarily inverting) before being re-established.
options.Innacurate: The Actor Earnings over Time chart should show the gap narrowing (and even temporarily inverting) before being re-established.

options.Perfect: You have the data split up into categories. Looking good.
options.Line Chart: This chart should be a bar chart to match the graphic. The way to correct this is to set the Year to Discrete.
options.Filters: The filters need revision. Gender should be set to male and female, the category should be restricted to actors and acresses, and the years should be limited to 2016 through 2020.
options.Field Error: The Sum of Pay should be in columns and a discrete Year followed by Gender should be in rows.

options.Perfect: Good work. This is a simple but effective chart that can get a quick read on the overall situation.
options.Not Averaged: Make sure to switch Pay to the Average to get an accurate read.
options.Field Error: For this chart, Gender should be in either columns or rows, and the Average of the Pay should be in the other.

options.Perfect: This is exactly how it should look and visually drives home the point.

This is perfectly executed. This is one of my favourite charts from all of Part 2 because of how much there is to explore with this. I highly recommend going back and thinking about all the threads there are to pull.
options.Filter Error: This chart has a filter error which makes it inaccurate. Missing the Gender filter does not change much, but the category filter can tell completely different stories depending on if it is activated. This is also a look at what other insights this dataset holds that are worth a second look.
options.Field Error (Sum): The Pay field should be averaged instead of summed. The difference between the two leads to drastically different takeaways.
options.Field Error: The Year should be continuous and in columns, and the Average of Pay should be in rows.

options.Yes: Respect is always due for attempting the LevelUp. This one is a more focused on the analysis, and brings forward some of those interesting threads sitting in the data.
options.No: I will always recommend trying out the LevelUp. Not only is it a good way to get some extra cushion on the evaluations, but you also get further opportunities to develop your skills. This one is a more focused on the analysis, and brings forward some of those interesting threads sitting in the data.

options.Perfect: The chart portion looks good. This visualization doesn't need to be perfect since the main focus is on the writing.

options.Concise: The LevelUp section is good and can be strengthened with a note expanding on observations.
options.Inaccurate: The LevelUp section is not accurate.

greeting.Needs Revision: This is good submission that needs revision
greeting.Insufficient: This milestone has good pieces to build on

intro.Superior: Professional execution, attention to detail, and effort. This is setting you up for success.
intro.Strong: Your work is accurate and demonstrates good effort. I recommend implementing the feedback when refining your milestone.
intro.Needs Revision: Revising your milestone will help you break down the road blocks you encountered, set you up for success with the portfolio project, and prepare this milestone for public sharing. If you spent a lot of time on this milestone and feel frustrated, taking some time away can let you process the problems in the background and reset your perspective.
intro.Insufficient: I can tell that this milestone was a challenge - either because something with the material didn't click or because you didn't have enough time to process. That's okay and happens to everyone. There's good work to build on here, and I have included detailed feedback to help you revise your submission. Revising your milestone will help you break down the road blocks you encountered, set you up for success with the portfolio project, and prepare this milestone for public sharing. If you spent a lot of time on this milestone and feel frustrated, taking some time away can let you process the problems in the background and reset your perspective.

conclusion.Superior: I look forward to seeing how you tackle the next one!
conclusion.Strong: I look forward to seeing how you tackle the next one!
conclusion.Needs Revision: There is a lot to be proud of, and if you have any questions then make sure to reach out. I look forward to seeing your continued development as a data visualizer!
conclusion.Insufficient: There is a lot to be proud of, and if you have any questions then make sure to reach out. If you get stuck on anything, make sure to use the skillbuilders, materials, drop-ins, and Bodhi your advantage. You got this!
